sections: There is a major player in the U.S. health care system that flies under the radar but wields tremendous power in determining who gets access to life-saving medication. A group of businesses called Pharmacy Benefit Managers, or PBMs, set prescription drug benefits nationwide ‚Äî and instead of passing savings they negotiate onto patients, these firms pocket the proceeds and reap gargantuan profits.

A tiny handful of PBMs, most of which are owned by insurers, control nearly the entire market, shape the benefits of hundreds of millions of Americans, and boast sky-high revenues ‚Äî yet most people don‚Äôt know they exist, and they have long skirted federal oversight.

‚ÄúAlthough many people have never heard of pharmacy benefit managers, these powerful middlemen have enormous influence over the U.S. prescription drug system,‚Äù said Federal Trade Commission (FTC) Chair Lina Khan in a June press release on the matter.
In today‚Äôs Cheat Sheet, exclusively for supporting subscribers, we will teach you all about PBMs, explain why they‚Äôre so dangerous, and highlight what can be done to stop them.

In the prescription drug supply chain, pharmacy benefit managers are companies that work with drugmakers, insurers, and pharmacies to determine drug benefits, which includes deciding which medicines will covered by health insurance plans and negotiating prescription drug prices with pharmaceutical manufacturers on behalf of insurers, Medicare‚Äôs prescription drug benefit plans, and large employers.

Theoretically, PBM brokers should help patients save money, since they negotiate discounts with pharmaceutical companies to get better deals for insurers and their patients. In reality, that‚Äôs not quite how they operate. Instead of passing rebates onto patients, PBMs pocket most of the savings, while making medicines costlier for patients.

The process goes like this: An insurance company tells a PBM to find the best price on, say, insulin, which is critical to diabetes treatment. The PBM will then figure out which drug company is willing to offer the insurer the biggest discount on the drug. PBMs get paid based on the discount they negotiate. The arrangement encourages profit-hungry drug manufacturers to jack up insulin prices before negotiating discounts, while PBMs are incentivized to discourage insurers from covering cheaper drugs, since they won‚Äôt score as much profit from the smaller rebates they‚Äôll net from these medications.

The specifics of how much cost savings PBMs pass on to insurers and patients versus how much they pocket themselves are extremely secretive, with the information shielded from insurers, government auditors, and the public alike. This has led to shady practices like spread pricing, in which PBMs charge insurers and employers more for medications than they pay to pharmacies for these drugs, pocketing the difference. That difference can add up: The Ohio State Auditor‚Äôs office found a
between what Medicaid paid its PBM for certain medications, and what the PBM paid to pharmacies in the state.

The PBM market is dominated by just three companies: OptumRx, Express Scripts, and CVS Caremark. These three companies manage a whopping

of all prescriptions in the U.S., meaning they have outsized influence in determining which medicines are covered by insurance and what patients are responsible for paying. Express Scripts, for example, covers

To make matters worse, the largest PBMs are all owned by major health insurance interests, which further entrenches the monopolization of health care in the hands of a few corporate giants. Insurer UnitedHealth owns OptumRx, while its counterpart Cigna owns Express Scripts. The pharmacy chain CVS Health, which purchased health insurer Aetna in 2018, owns CVS Caremark.

Here‚Äôs a helpful video from ophthalmologist Will Flanary that breaks down how PBMs and the broader vertical integration scheme in which they are embedded translate to billions of dollars in profit for insurance companies annually.

While patients and providers can bypass a PBM‚Äôs list of covered medications to obtain other, cheaper drugs, to do so they must navigate a tedious prior authorization process to prove that a patient needs a drug that is different from the one chosen for them by the PBM ‚Äî which is easier said than done.
